basics.name: Dhruva Bansal
label: Computer Scientist
Machine Learning Researcher
Tech Enthusiast
basics.summary: Hey there! I am Dhruva Bansal (pronounced Dhruv) and I am an MS CS student at Stanford University, specializing in Artificial Intelligence. As a Research Engineering Intern at DeepMind Google, I am working along the intersection of ML research and products that touch millions of people around the globe. In the past, I have worked on exciting problems at Amazon Robotics and Honeywell as a Software Engineering Intern. Feel free to reach out if you like what you see, are working on interesting projects, or just wanna say hi!

work.summary: Integrating DeepMind’s state-of-the-art research in Natural language and Meta learning into innovative products at Google.
Colaborating with Prof. Fei-Fei Li, Prof. Jiajun Wu, and Dr. Ruohan Zhang on novel Reinforcement Learning algorithms for Robotic applications.
work.summary1: Exploring how human feedback may be used alongside environment reward to train agents for sparse reward, long horizon tasks. Integrating Soft Actor-Critic with TAMER to leverage human feedback and learn in continuous environments.
work.summary2: Formalized and implemented a novel Bandit-based RL algorithm in PyTorch to learn tasks using human feedback at 10x sample efficiency. Paper in review at Corl 2022.

work.summary: Entered Stanford University as an MS CS student specializing in AI.
Owned a service that leveraged state-of-the-art computer vision to automate configuration of station used by associates to interact with robots.
work.summary1: Trained ResNet-34 and Darknet-53 models on 50+ warehouses to compute unknown parameters and enable automation. Employed evaluation metrics such as IoU to verify the service’s 99.95% accuracy in computing parameters on the test set.
work.summary2: Architected and containerized production-ready training and inference pipelines using Python, PyTorch, and Docker. Deployed inference pipelines to AWS using a Flask-based webserver, SageMaker, EC2, Lambda, S3, DynamoDB, and SNS. Expedited warehouse operations, reduced associate workload, and eliminated dependencies without sacrificing accuracy.

work.summary: Graduated from Georgia Tech with a BS in CS with threads in Intelligence and Theory.
Collaborated with Prof. Sonia Chernova and Dr. Harish Ravichandar on topics in robot trajectory optimization and knowledge graphs inference.
work.summary1: Leveraged deep learning and path ranking algorithms for building commonsense for robots. Implemented Transformers in PyTorch for commonsense reasoning, outperforming baselines by 11% on search accuracy. This work lead to our paper titled "LINK: Learning Instance-Level N-Ary Semantic Knowledge At Scale For Robots Operating in Everyday Environments" (published at RSS'21)
work.summary2: Built intelligent robots that adapt behavior to stochastic human motion, thereby allowing safe and comfortable collaboration with humans. Developed pipelines to predict human motion using Gaussian Mixture Models for trajectory optimization in Python, C++, and ROS. This work lead to our paper titled "Anticipatory Human-Robot Collaboration via Multi-Objective Trajectory Optimization" (published at IROS’20)

work.summary: Developed upon Honeywell Connected Plant's backend API to support analysis and visualization of warehouses.
work.summary1: Built a web app in Python using TensorFlow, OpenCV and Scikit-learn to analyze and extract relational data from scanned images.
work.summary2: Developed upon Honeywell Connected Plant API using Node.js and MongoDB to provide granular insight into warehouse equipment and usage. Wrote production ready code for handling upwards of 3 million requests every month.

work.summary: Collaborated with Prof. Thad Starner on the application of American Sign Language towards creating a game for deaf children.
work.summary1: Built a sign verification system using pose estimation libraries such as MediaPipe and combined them with pattern recognition models such as Hidden Markov Models and Transformers implemented using Python and PyTorch.
work.summary2: Demonstrated that HMMs outperform Transformers for American Sign Language recognition by on average 17% in real-world scenarios. Our results have been published in the paper titled "CopyCat: Using Sign Language Recognition to Help Deaf Children Acquire Language Skills" at CHI'21

work.summary: Entered Georgia Tech as a undergraduate student majoring in CS.

projects.name: CopyCat
projects.description: A game which leverages Sign Language recognition to help deaf children acquire short term memory skills. Uses pose estimation to extract landmarks and models like HMMs and Transformers for recognizing video sequences.

projects.name: Translation
projects.description: In collaboration with Facebook AI, built classifiers for deciding whether translations produced by Transformers are sufficiently good. Uses language models in conjunction with manual feature engineering to train logistic classifiers for the task.

projects.name: LfD
projects.description: Learning agent (Ant-V2) behavior from demonstration using inverse reinforcement learning. We first adapt MixText to identification of trajectories and suboptimal and then integrate it with 2IWIL for learning from demonstrations.

projects.name: SoundSight
projects.description: SoundSight uses computer vision to collect spatial data in the user's immediate vicinity and converts it into 3 dimensional sound allowing complete perception of the environment without the visual senses.

projects.name: SAO
projects.description: Study Alexa Online (SAO) makes collaborative studying easier by turning the Alexa into a tool to connect to the collectively knowledge of other peers. Students connect to study groups via the SAO Alexa skill.

projects.name: Golden Gate
projects.description: Finds news articles covering similar content to provide all perspectives on a topic. We analyze author attitudes using sentiment analysis and find other articles with differing attitudes to provide a comprehesive view.

projects.name: Isomathic
projects.description: Isomathic is a tool for converting handwritten math into LaTex documents. The tool uses OpenCV to extract blocks of text, processes them using Mathpix, and then displays the resulting LaTex file on the website.

researchArticles.name: Bachelor Thesis
researchArticles.description: Bachelor Thesis titled "Leveraging 2D pose estimators for American Sign Language Recognition"

researchArticles.name: LINK
researchArticles.description: Learning Instance-Level N-Ary Semantic Knowledge At Scale For Robots Operating in Everyday Environments. In Proceedings of Robotics: Science and Systems 2021.

researchArticles.name: CopyCat
researchArticles.description: CopyCat: Using Sign Language Recognition to Help Deaf Children Acquire Language Skills. In Extended Abstracts of the 2021 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI EA '21).

researchArticles.name: CoMOTO
researchArticles.description: Anticipatory Human-Robot Collaboration via Multi-Objective Trajectory Optimization. In Proceedings of the 2020 IEEE/RSJ International Conference on Intelligent Robots and Systems (IROS)

researchArticles.name: Surface++
researchArticles.description: Surface++: A Scalable and Self-sustainable Wireless Sound Sensing Surface. In Proceedings of the 17th Annual International Conference on Mobile Systems, Applications, and Services (MobiSys '19).

Awards.name: CHI'21
Awards.description: [May 2021] First place at the CHI 2021 Student Research Competition (Undergraduate division)

Awards.name: CoC Awards'21
Awards.description: [April 2021] Outstanding Undergraduate Researcher awarded by Georgia Tech College of Computing (CoC).

Awards.name: PURA
Awards.description: [Dec 2020] President's Undergraduate Research Award (PURA) for funding progress on the CopyCat project.

Awards.name: MobiSys'19
Awards.description: [June 2019] Best Poster Award for the Surface++ research project at MobiSys'19 conference.

Awards.name: HackGT 5
Awards.description: [Oct 2018] Best Accessibility Hack at HackGT 5 for the Isomathic project.
